           Sulfur  dioxide is supplied as a liquefied  gas  under
       high  pressure from two (3) 1-ton containers with two  (2)
       additional 1-ton containers online in standby  mode.   The
       maximum  inventory for sulfur dioxide  is  six  (2)  1-ton

       include  component  specifications, operating  parameters,
       and maintenance procedures, may be found in Appendix C.

   C.  Process

           The  sulfonation  system includes the  sulfur  dioxide
       supply,  sulfonators, and inductors.  The  sulfur  dioxide
       inductor  is  the controlling component.  The inductor  is
       used  to  create a vacuum that is used to draw the  sulfur
       dioxide gas from the sulfur dioxide container through  the
       sulfonator, and into the inductor.  The sulfonator  meters
       the  volume of sulfur dioxide to the inductor, the  sulfur
       dioxide  dissolves  in the water to form  sulfurous  acid.
       From  the  inductor, the sulfurous acid solution flows  to
       the point where it is injected into the wastewater.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


We have adopted this Program in order to implement 40 C.F.R. 68, the federal requirements regulating Risk Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.

This Program will help prevent the occurrence of, or minimize the consequences of, catastrophic releases by stating our policies and procedures for the management of process hazards in start-up, operation, inspection, maintenance and the other matters addressed in the federal standard.

Our Program calls for maximum employee participation and includes all elements of the employee participation provisions of the standard.  We shall, as a minimum: (1) consult with employees and their representatives on the conduct and development of the process hazard review and other elements of the risk management plan, and (2) provide to our employees and their representatives access to the process hazard review and all other information required to be developed under that standard.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The City of Galveston believes that preventative maintenance is the key to minimizing the potential for accidental releases.  Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) have been reviewed and revised to enable the employees to perform their work in a safe and efficient manner.

The EPA has adopted a policy for non-responding facilities (another entity has agreed in advance to respond to the release).  This facility is a non-responding facility.  The City of Galveston Fire Department is the first responder.

This emergency response program does not include responses to incidental releases of hazardous substances, including chlorine and sulfur dioxide, where the substances can be ¿adsorbed, neutralized, or otherwise controlled at the time of the release by employees in the immediate release area, or by maintenance personnel¿.

The City of Galveston has taken steps to train the operators, supervisors, and maintenance crews to be knowledgeable in the emergency response program.  The t

raining includes classroom and hands on training on the proper use of emergency response equipment and procedures.  Above all, all employees know where the phone numbers of the first responders are located should a release occur.
The Airport Wastewater Treatment Plant utilizes chlorine for disinfection and sulfur dioxide for dechlorination of the treated wastewater.

The offsite consequence analysis includes a worst-case release scenario and an alternative release scenario as defined in 40 C.F.R. 68.  A dense-gas dispersion model (SLAB) was used to determine endpoint distances for both scenarios.  A dense-gas model is required since both chlorine and sulfur dioxide are heavier than air.

The City of Galveston has implemented a General Accidental Release Prevention Program to minimize releases.  This Program includes:  safety information on the covered chemicals, hazard reviews, operating and maintenance procedures, training, compliance audits, incident investigations, and emergency response procedures.

Five-year Accident History

In the last 5 years, there have not been any accidental releases from the covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The city will address the recommendations of the process hazards assessment for all areas of the prevention program and the emergency response program.

II.  CHLORINATION PROCESS

   A.  Process Chemistry
     
          Chlorine  is used to disinfect the wastewater  effluent
       prior   to   discharging   into   the   receiving   water.
       Chlorination  capacities are generally  selected  to  meet
       the  specific  design  criteria  of  the  state  or  other
       regulatory  agencies  controlling the  receiving  body  of
       water.   In  any case, where the residual in the  effluent
       is  specified or the final number of coliform bacteria  is
       limited,  the actual amount of chlorine must be determined
       by onsite testing.
     
       The general chlorination equation is as follows:
     
               Cl2 + H2O  HOCl + H+ + Cl-

           This equilibrium is the dominant one in chlorine water
       from  vacuum chlorinators with a pH of 2 to 3, and at  the
       instant  of contact, when chlorine water is added  to  any
       water  for disinfection.  The free chlorine dominates  the
       nature   of   the  reactions.   These  often   result   in
       development  of  obnoxious  compounds  such  as   nitrogen
       trichloride, NCl3.
       
       A. Process Chemistry (Continued)

           To minimize these effects, high quality water is often
       used  as  chlorinator  feed  water  and  flash  mixing  is
       required at the point where the chlorine water is  applied
       to   prevent

the   development  of  localized   low   pH
       conditions.   In  dilute solution and at pH  levels  above
       about  4, the equilibrium shown above is displaced greatly
       to  the right, and very little chlorine exists as such  in
       solution.   The hypochlorous acid formed is  a  weak  acid
       and is very poorly dissociated at pH levels below 6.

   B.  Maximum Inventory

           Chlorine  is  supplied as a liquefied gas  under  high
       pressure  from three (3) 1-ton containers with  three  (3)
       additional 1-ton containers online in standby  mode.   The
       maximum   inventory  for  chlorine  is  ten   (10)   1-ton
       containers.   Equipment manuals, which  include  component
       specifications,  operating  parameters,  and   maintenance
       procedures, may be found in Appendix B.


   C.  Process
     
           The  chlorination system includes the chlorine supply,
       chlorinators,  and  inductors.  The chlorine  inductor  is
       the  controlling  component.   The  inductor  is  used  to
       create  a  vacuum  that is used to draw the  chlorine  gas
       from  the chlorine container through the chlorinator,  and
       into  the inductor.  The chlorinator meters the volume  of
       chlorine  solution to the inductor, the chlorine dissolves
       in water to form hypochlorous acid.

           The contact time and the chlorine residual are the two
       principal   factors   involved  in   achieving   effective
       bacterial kill.  The contact time is specified by the  EPA
       and  is a minimum of 20 minutes.  The appropriate chlorine
       residual  is monitored and controlled by residual chlorine
       testing.   The permitted limits for chlorine residual  are
       1.0  mg/l  prior  to dechlorination and 0.1  mg/l  in  the
       effluent prior to the receiving water.
